Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



Radford Army Ammunition Plant (RFAAP) is a government-owned, contractor-operated facility located in Radford, Virginia. RFAAP is owned by the U.S. Department of the Army, and is currently operated under contract by BAE Systems, Ordnance Systems Inc. effective 1 July 2012. RFAAP has been in continuous operation since 1941. RFAAP maintains an accidental release prevention program that covers design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, management of change, and employee training associated with the facility's processes. RFAAP maintains 24/7 on-site security and fire services, and coordinates with the Montgomery County Local Emergency Response Committee to provide additional emergency response expertise if needed.



Regulated Substances at RFAAP



The primary operations at RFAAP are propellant manufacturing processes for both military and commercial purposes. In support of these operations, RFAAP maintains more than the threshold planning quantity of four regulated substances: nitric acid (CAS No. 7697-37-2), ethyl ether (60-29-7), ammonia (7664-41-7) and oleum (8014-95-7); therefore, RFAAP is subject to the requirements of the RMP Rule (40 CFR Part 68). As all of RFAAP's RMP-covered processes directly support, the facility's primary activity is defined under NAICS Code 32592 for Explosives Manufacturing. 



RMP Covered Processes at RFAAP



The RMP covered processes at RFAAP as of the October 2020 5-year update are summarized as follows:

-- Ethyl ether in combined storage and manufacturing processes (inclusive of Solvent Recovery, Activated Carbon Recovery System and all associated storage). Despite the geographical areas covered by these processes, these components are considered one single process of interconnected piping and vessels.

-- Ethyl ether in Transient Railcar Storage. 

-- Ammonia in Bulk Tanks at the Acid Area and Associated Piping to the C-Line Nitrocellulose Area for use

at the SCR.

-- Ammonia in Tankage and Piping at the D-Line Nitrocellulose Area for use at the SCR.

--Nitric Acid in bulk storage at the Acid Area and satellite tankage at the C-Line and D-Line Nitrocellulose Areas, and all associated piping inclusive of transfer lines from the NAC/SAC. These are considered one single RMP-covered process of interconnected piping and vessels.

--Nitric Acid and Oleum in Transient Railcar Storage. 

--Oleum in NGMA Tankage and Piping at the Nitroglycerin Area for use in the manufacturing process.

--Oleum in bulk storage at the Acid Area and satellite tankage at both the C-Line and D-Line Nitrocellulose Areas, and all associated transfer piping. These are considered one single RMP-covered process of interconnected piping and vessels.



Once completion of the extended commissioning and prove-out period process for the new D-Line Nitrocellulose Area is completed, the C-Line Nitrocellulose Area will be permanently shutdown.  At this time, the C-Line Nitrocellulose Area components will be removed from the oleum and nitric acid RMP processes for the consolidated Acid and Nitrocellulose Areas tankage and piping process.  Additionally, the ammonia RMP-process for Acid Area tankage and piping supportive of the C-Line SCR system will also be removed.



Five-Year Accident History



The five-year accident history was evaluated for this 2020 RMP update. For documentation purposes, RFAAP's onsite version of its RMP document summarizes and evaluates all release events associated with each covered process, regardless of severity (i.e., inclusive of minor leaks contained entirely within secondary containment and with no personnel exposure). On an ongoing basis in order to identify the occurrence of any events that trigger the RMP update requirements to EPA, all incidents of safety and environmental significant must be promptly reported to management and each incident investigated. 



During the 2015-2020 5-year accident history period covered by

this current RMP update to EPA, no qualifying events were identified for any of RFAAP's covered processes. Although in this time period, RFAAP did have several acid spills that were reportable to the National Response Center on the basis of exceeding their applicable reportable quantity thresholds, none of these events resulted in either offsite damages to the public or the environment, or onsite injuries, deaths, or significant property damage.



Off-Site Consequences Analysis - Worst Case



As required by the RMP rule, Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios for Off-Site Consequences Analysis were developed.  Per EPA's guidance, the intention of these scenarios is to provide a basis for planning and discussion among the regulated community, emergency responders, and the public, rather than a basis for any specific actions. Of the RMP-covered processes modeled for RFAAP, two (2) processes were addressed as flammable substance scenarios, four (4) were addressed as toxic liquids stored at ambient conditions (oleum and nitric acid), and two (2) were modelled as a toxic gas stored under pressure (anhydrous ammonia). 



Due to the size of the RFAAP facility, a distance of 0.8 mi is required to cause impacts to public receptors at the Army Staff Village area. Worst-Case scenarios were evaluated for all covered processes identified in the 2020 RMP, with addition of the Nitrocellulose D-Line ammonia bulk storage and piping and oleum within NGMA Storage at the Nitroglycerin Manufacturing Area. RFAAP followed EPA's Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance in developing the Worst-Case release scenarios, and verified the results via RMP*Comp against the results obtained from the EPA's Guidance Reference Tables and Equations.  As required by the guidance, the worst-case release scenarios were modeled using the worst meteorological conditions, which are a wind speed of 1.5 meters per second and an atmospheric stability class of F. EPA's web-based RMP*Comp indicated that the worst case release modeling would yield an endpoint distance of 3.8 miles and impacts to a population of 6,877. Based on a review of the USGS Survey Maps for the area covered by the release, potential public receptors include residential areas, schools, and recreational areas (New River). This is the required assumption for the worst-case modeling for this scenario, as the tanker cars are not stored within a secondary containment or impoundment. It is for this reason that although the total volume of the release is larger for the bulk storage tanks of nitric acid and oleum, the endpoint distances are larger for a railcar release since the surface area of the pool is not constrained by a dike.  For a strong nitric acid railcar, the worst case release modeling indicated an endpoint distance of 16.0 miles and impacts to a population of 140,714.  An oleum railcar worst case release would result in an endpoint distance of 12.0 mils and impacts to a population of 78,660. Based on a review of the USGS Survey Ma

Worst Case for Ether Processes: The worst-case release scenario associated with the ethyl ether process group was modeled as a vapor cloud explosion from one of the ether bulk storage tanks containing 296,662 lbs, which is the largest individual vessel in the process. As this is a flammable substance, it is assumed that the entire quantity is released as a vapor, which finds an ignition source, with 10 percent of the released quantity participating in a vapor cloud detonation. The endpoint distance resulting from this scenario is 0.5 mi to 1 psi overpressure, which is contained entirely within the facility fenceline and does not result in impacts to the nearest public receptor. Therefore, this process qualifies as a Program 1.



Worst Case for Ether Railcar Storage: The worst-case release scenario associated with the ethyl ether transient railcar storage was modeled as a vapor cloud explosion of a single railcar containing 178,626 lbs. As this is a flammable substance, it is assumed that the entire quantity is released as a vapor, which finds an ignition source, with 10 percent of the released quantity participating in a vapor cloud detonation. The endpoint distance resulting from this scenario is 0.4 mi to 1 psi overpressure, which is contained entirely within the facility fenceline and does not result in impacts to the nearest public receptor.  Therefore, this process qualifies as a Program 1.

Worst Case for Oleum in NGMA Storage and Piping at the Nitroglycerin Area: Nitroglycerin Mixed Acid (NGMA) is comprised of a mixture of nitric acid (below RMP threshold concentrations) and oleum.  Although a legacy process to the facility, this process was not historically identified as RMP-covered because the Safety Data Sheets document this material as a nearly 50-50 mixture of nitric and sulfuric. However, because of NGMA's negative water value, the material should be considered as a mixture of nitric acid and oleum instead. The worst-case release scenario associated with oleum in NGMA storage and piping assumes that the volume of the one of the NGMA storage tanks at the Nitroglycerin Area (163,248 lbs) is immediately released into secondary containment. The release rate is based on the rate of evaporation from the resulting pool within the dike. EPA's web-based RMP*Comp indicated that the worst case release modeling would yield an endpoint distance of 3.6 miles and impacts to a population of 6,057. Based on a review of the USGS Survey Maps for the area covered by the release, potential public receptors include residential areas, schools, and recreational areas (New River), with the Jefferson National Forest also identified as a potential environmental receptor for this release. However the RMP*Comp endpoint distance of 3.6 miles is substantively higher than that yielded from application of the EPA Guidance Worksheets and Calculations (1.6 miles). Using this latter method results in population impacts of 335, and would result in impacts to residential and recreational areas, but not to schools or environmental receptors. Of note in determining the population impacts, the oleum

in NGMA storage utilizes a different methodology than the other RMP-covered processes at RFAAP due to its location being remote to the Main Manufacturing Area where the other processes are located. Using either endpoint distance value, this process qualifies as a Program 3.



Worst Case for Oleum Storage and Transfer Piping (Acid Area, Legacy C-Line Nitrocellulose Area, D-Nitrocellulose Area): The worst-case release scenario associated with oleum in interconnected storage and piping at the Acid Legacy C-Line Nitrocellulose and D-Line Nitrocellulose Areas assumes that the volume of the largest storage tank at the Acid Area Tank Farm (823,816lbs) is immediately released into secondary containment. The release rate is based on the rate of evaporation from the resulting pool within the dike. EPA's web-based RMP*Comp indicated that the worst case release modeling would yield an endpoint distance of 11.0 miles and impacts to a population of 65,916. Based on a review of the USGS Survey Maps for the area covered by the release, potential public receptors include residential areas, schools, and recreational areas (New River), with the Jefferson National Forest also identified as a potential environmental receptor for this release. However the RMP*Comp endpoint distance of 3.6 miles is substantively higher than that yielded from application of the EPA Guidance Worksheets and Calculations (3.5 miles). Using this latter method results in population impacts of 5,663, and would also result in impacts to residential and recreational areas, schools and environmental receptors. Using either value, this process qualifies as a Program 3.



Worst Case for Anhydrous Ammonia in Storage and Transfer Piping: The worst-case release scenario associated with anhydrous ammonia in storage and piping assumes that the volume of a single storage tank at the Acid Area (170,000 lbs) is immediately released into secondary containment. The release rate is based on the rate of evaporation from the r

esulting pool within the dike. The worst case release modeling indicated an endpoint distance of 4.4 miles and impacts to a population of 6,902. Based on a review of the USGS Survey Maps for the area covered by the release, potential public receptors include residential areas, schools, and recreational areas (New River). There are no environmental receptors identified for this release. Therefore, this process qualifies as a Program 3.



Worst Case for Anhydrous Ammonia in Satellite Storage and Piping at the D-Line Nitrocellulose Area: The worst-case release scenario associated with anhydrous ammonia in storage and piping assumes that the volume of a one of the two storage tanks at the D-Line Nitrocellulose Area (51,500 lbs) is immediately released into secondary containment. The release rate is based on the rate of evaporation from the resulting pool within the dike. The worst case release modeling indicated an endpoint distance of 2.6 miles and impacts to a population of 2,621. Based on a review of the USGS Survey Maps for the area covered by the release, potential public receptors include residential areas, schools, and recreational areas (New River). There are no environmental receptors identified for this release. Therefore, this process qualifies as a Program 3.



Off-Site Consequences Analysis - Alternate Release



EPA requires that per 40 CFR 68.165(a), "the owner or operator of Program 2 and 3 processes shall also submit information on one alternative release scenario for each regulated toxic substance held above the threshold and one alternative release scenario to represent all regulated flammable substances held above the threshold quantity." Unlike the worst-case scenario which is explicitly prescribed by the EPA, the alternative release scenario is intended to be representative of the types of releases which may be encountered at the facility, or which possibly have already been encountered. No alternative release scenarios were considered for flamma

ble substances, as all covered processes for ether were determined to be Program Level 1. Per the EPA's Risk Management Program Guidance for Offsite Consequence Analysis, "alternative scenarios are not required for Program 1 processes." Based on the requirements of 40 CFR Part 68.28(a), the minimum alternate release scenario requirements for RFAAP are one scenario each for: (1) ammonia, (2) SNA, and (3) oleum. 



Unlike the worst-case scenario which prescribes consideration of the instantaneous release of the maximum quantity from the largest pipeline or vessel in a process, the alternative release quantity is based on the specific scenario. Therefore, development of the overall quantity as derived from the release rate and duration of release are dependent on the specifics of the alternative release scenario selected. Each individual alternative release scenario was evaluated to determine what level of mitigation is considered credible and appropriate based on the specifics of the each scenario. RFAAP considered multiple potential scenarios for each regulated substance, and subjected them to sensitivity analysis for emergency response planning purposes.  To facilitate this exercise, RFAAP utilized RMP*Comp for the modeling, in consultation with the guidance presented in EPA's Risk Management Program Guidance for Offsite Consequence Analysis. All modeling was performed under meteorological conditions considering a wind speed of 3 meters per second and an atmospheric stability class of D. 



Anhydrous Ammonia Alternate Release Scenario:  The previously submitted 2015 RMP alternate release scenario for ammonia utilized one of the bulk tanks in the Acid Area tank farm. As these ammonia tanks will be officially decommissioned once the C-Line Nitrocellulose Area also is shutdown, the alternate release scenario for the 2020 RMP update utilized a similar failure mode but instead tailored and applied to the D-Line NC Area ammonia storage process.  The scenario developed f

or ammonia assumes that a hole has developed in the liquid space of a single ammonia tank at D-Line ammonia storage, via either flange failure, pipe shearing, weld failure, or potential puncture from an external impact, representing a 10 sq-in area of tank compromise. This failure mode was considered appropriate for this analysis due to being more credible for use in disaster planning purposes for the facility, and less duplicative than modeling a tank failure which was already evaluated under the worst-case scenario analysis. Administrative controls prevent filling of the ammonia tanks to greater than 80% of capacity, which is equivalent to a liquid height of approximately 85 inches above the tank bottom. As sensitivity analysis indicated that this scenario is completely insensitive to the duration used in the modeling, a duration of 10 minutes was selected. Only active mitigation is considered for this scenario based on the activation of the Halo water curtain system within the tank location. An effectiveness of 50% for the Halo system was assumed, although a range of effectiveness was also assessed through sensitivity analysis in order to provide a reference for use in emergency planning and response. The release modeling for the selected alternate scenario for ammonia indicated an endpoint distance of 0.6 miles based on RMP*Comp. As the closest public receptor would be the Army Staff Village at 0.8 miles, there are no potential public receptors or environmental receptors associated with this scenario.



Nitric Acid Alternate Release Scenario: The alternate release scenario developed for nitric acid assumes that a failure occurs at the 3" transfer line between the bulk storage at the Acid Area and the day tank at the D-Line Nitrocellulose Area. Comparative sensitivity analysis evaluated a range of pipe failure scenarios that could result in failure of the line due to shearing (e.g., external impact) or flange failure; the selected scenario utilized a pipe flow l

oss of 50% of the material.  The typical operational flowrate of this line during transfer is approximately 100 gallons/min. The release was considered as unmitigated due to the lack of a secondary containment dike at the inter-area location where the failure would to occur. Acid transfers occur even at night, and although the two area's operators are in communication every 30 minutes, especially a partial loss of the transfer volume would not be likely identified and responded by the operators until after a period of time had elapsed. Therefore, release durations ranging from 15 up to 60 minutes were considered via sensitivity analysis, which is the average time-to-completion for a nitric acid transfer between the Nitrocellulose and Acid Areas; an event duration of 45 minutes was selected for this scenario. The release modeling for the selected alternate scenario for nitric acid indicated an endpoint distance of 1.1 miles based on RMP*Comp, and a population impacted by this release is estimated at 50. The size of the public population impacted by this release is estimated at 50 based upon the maximum capacity of Staff Village, as a 1.1 mile endpoint distance is not within offsite residential receptors. No schools, recreational areas, or environmental receptors are identified for this release.



Oleum Alternate Release Scenario: The previous 2015 RMP alternate release scenario for oleum utilized the catastrophic release event on 1 July 2012 at the Legacy C-Line Nitrocellulose Area acid storage tank battery. As this is an event of historical significance for the facility, the previous modeling is retained in RFAAP's internal RMP version for lessons-learned purposes. However, as this C-Line tankage will be officially decommissioned once the Legacy Nitrocellulose Area also is shutdown, the alternate release scenario for the 2020 RMP update utilized a more realistic tank failure mode applied to the Acid Area Tank farm bulk storage, which will continue operating to prov

ide material to the D-Line Nitrocellulose Area.  An alternate scenario was considered for oleum involving development of an erosion/corrosion hole 40% from the bottom one of oleum bulk storage tanks in the Acid Area. As the majority of erosive/corrosive failures occur at the vapor-liquid interface, selecting a release point 40% from the bottom of the tank would also be a reasonable location exposed during the usage cycles between refilling. The release was considered to be mitigated by the secondary containment dike at the oleum and sulfuric acid tank component of the Acid Area Tank Farm. Comparative sensitivity analysis was applied to a range of release durations ranging from to up to 90 minutes, and multiple degrees of tank corrosive damage (ranging from a ?u"-D pinhole leak to a 6"-D area of tank compromise); all of these possibilities are considered plausible as an initial pinhole compromise can rapidly evolve to a larger damaged area due to the corrosion characteristics of strong acids. The selected scenario utilized a 4"-D hole in the compromised tank surface and a release duration of 60 minutes, and resulted in an endpoint distance of 0.3 miles. The closest residential receptor would be the Army Staff Village (population of 50 at maximum), which is located 0.8 miles from the release location. Therefore, there are no other offsite public receptors or environmental receptors within this potential area of impact for the oleum alternate release scenario. 



Accidental Release Prevention Program



The following sections summarize the components of RFAAP's Accidental Release Prevention Program, as required under 40 CFR Part 68. In addition to RMP Program Level 3 processes, a number of processes at the facility are also subject to the OSHA process safety management (PSM) standard under 29 CFR 1910.119. Therefore, RFAAP's Accidental Release Prevention Program is tailored to assure compliance under both the RMP and PSM regulations. 



Process Safety Information: RF

AAP maintains records of safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all covered processes.



Process Hazard Analysis: RFAAP's Plant Protection Standard 1.05 - Process Hazard Analysis and Engineering Standard OSI-PSM-PHA -Process Hazard Analysis detail RFAAP's requirements for conducting both initial and updated PHAs in a manner compliant with 29 CFR Part !?1910.119(e). All critical safety actions prompted by PHA recommendations are required to be completed prior to process startup, and non-critical items are required to be completed within the timeframe established by the PHA. The required PHA revalidation frequency is specified as at least every five years after completion of the initial PHA to ensure consistency with the as-built design. All covered process PHAs were initiated within 5-years of the previous 2015 PHAs, although at the time of the October 2020 submittal and update to EPA, finalization of several of the associated reports are still in progress.



Operating Procedures: All operating procedures are available to all employees through the Document Control System, and the operators are routinely retrained on these procedures. Consistent with the requirements of 40 CFR Part !?68.69(a)(1), the process operating procedures contain steps for each operating phase, inclusive of initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and startup following a turnaround or emergency shutdown. RFAAP's operating procedures also include information on the operating limits of each process, inclusive of the consequences of deviation from these limits and the steps required to correct or avoid deviation. Procedures are subjected to a routine review and recertification to assure that the contained information is correct and up-to-date.



Training: RFAAP has a dedicated Training Department which holds the primary responsibility for conduc

ting personnel training and also serves as the central repository for the maintenance of training records for all plant personnel. Each employee involved in the operation of any process at RFAAP is trained on the applicable Operating Procedures. All training includes emphasis of the specific safety and health hazards associated with the equipment and chemicals involved, as well as emergency operation and safe work practices. Initial training for each operator consists of reading the procedure, and being instructed firsthand on process operations via a walkthrough with the procedure in-hand. Upon any procedure change, each operator is retrained using the same methods as for initial training. The Training Department maintains a database of each employee's required training, including the date of the initial training, the date of the most recent training, and the date that the next refresher training is required.



Mechanical Integrity: RFAAP has established written procedures to ensure the ongoing integrity of process equipment and that employees are trained in conducing these maintenance activities. Additionally, the facility has an overarching Maintenance Plan which documents the Preventative Maintenance and Inspection System. The aspects of this plan satisfy the requirements of 40 CFR !?68.73 for addressing the ongoing mechanical integrity of pressure vessels and storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems and devices, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps. The centralized planning and tracking system of the Preventative Maintenance (PM) system at RFAAP is Maximo, which is an asset management software platform used to track the frequency of PMs and the date that the PM is closed. In the event that a defect is observed during a PM and additional work is required, the defect is noted on the work order, the original PM is closed, and a "PM Defect" work order is issued to track the corrective action to completion.



Management of Change: Manageme

nt of Change is addressed in PM-eMOC - Radford Army Ammunition PSM Program Document, and all requests for process changes regardless of size must be entered into the Electronic Configuration Control System - Change Request. Additionally, Form DUP-9728 - Level of Risk Assessment for Management of Change is used to determine the associated level of risk for a change. 



The Plant Process Control Board (PPCB) is also a key component of RFAAP's overall Management of Change framework, and governs both process and non-process changes. Management Manual MM 1-1.02 - Plant Process Control Board (PPCB) documents this process and aids in ensuring that the applicable requirements of OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119, EPA 40 CFR Part 68, International Organization for Standardization (ISO) 9001 are met. 



An additional key Management of Change tool utilized at RFAAP is its computer-based Management of Change (MOC) system that can be accessed through any plant computer with network access. In addition to providing a centralized source for accessing the current operating procedures and associated controlled documents, this system also tracks the review and approval process for the appropriate personnel prior to procedure change implementation. 



Pre-startup Reviews: RFAAP's requirements and overall process for pre-startup safety reviews (PSSR) are documented in DUP-9483 - Pre-Startup Safety Review, and also discussed in Plant Protection Standard PPS 1.05 -Process Hazard Analysis.  Prior to start-up, a Pre-Startup Safety Review Checklist form (included in DUP-9483) must be completed and reviewed. The associated checklist ensures that procedures are in place and adequate, a hazards review has been performed as appropriate, and training has been completed prior to startup. Depending on the level of complexity of the process change involved, either the Short Form or Long Form of the checklist must be completed.  Completed and approved checklist forms are retained, at a minimum, until the next

5-year Process Hazard Analysis revalidation for the subject process is performed.  



A pre-startup review is not only required at RFAAP upon start-up of a new process or upon modification of an existing process, but also following an incident that results in a production shutdown, significant equipment damage, or injury. Following such an event, an incident investigation is conducted and followed up a management review. The root cause failure investigation results and associated corrective actions are evaluated by the PPCB team, and additional corrective actions will be recommended if necessary. The PPCB may request a follow-up review be held prior to operation start-up once to ensure critical corrective actions are completed before the startup can occur.



Incident Investigation: RFAAP's Plant Protection Standard 1.77 - Safety Incident Reporting & Investigation Requirements describes the reporting and investigation requirements for events involving explosions, motor vehicle incidents, severe storm or weather damage and spills with occupational injuries. Per this written procedure, the "investigation team must be formed and the investigation started as soon as possible based on the class of the incident and the conditions surrounding the incident and affected area." RFAAP's Management Manual 3-1.01 - Environmental Quality and Safety Incident Reporting additionally describes the process for incidents that are classified as environmental in nature and do not necessarily trigger the Safety incident requirements. All spills at RFAAP are required to be reported and investigated as Environmental events, even if the event is a nominal release entirely contained within secondary containment and without resulting in any health or safety impacts. Investigation of even minor events and near-misses is considered a means of identifying and addressing potential issues, and thereby preventing more significant events. The incident investigation report is reviewed with all affec

ted personnel and all incident investigation reports are retained for a minimum of five years.



Employee Participation: The Employee Safety Committee is established at RFAAP to promote safety compliance at the Radford Army Ammunition Plant. Through this forum, employees are able to meet monthly to identify and discuss safety and health issues and propose recommendations to the management team. Employee involvement in incident investigations and Process Hazard Analyses is also required at RFAAP. Per Plant Protection Standard 1.77 - Safety Incident Reporting and Investigation Requirements, all incident investigation teams are required to include employees representing Operations, Maintenance, and Wage Employees as core team members. Plant Protection Standard 1.05 - Process Hazard Analysis describes RFAAP's requirements for employee participation, as representatives from multiple functional areas are required to be on the team.



Contractors: All contractors, subcontractors and tenants at RFAAP are required to read and certify by signature that they understand and will abide by the rules identified in the General Plant Rules for Contractors, Subcontractors, Tenants and Government Employees. Representatives from Safety, at a minimum, attend a Pre-Work meeting to ensure that this information is clearly communicated. The booklet includes information ranging from general safety procedures, such as ladder use and hot work, as well as facility-specific hazards.



Compliance Audits: RFAAP Environmental is responsible for initiating, conducting, and documenting the RMP Compliance Audits on a minimum of a 3-year cycle. Any identified deficiencies are documented in the associated report, and tracking-to-resolution of proposed corrective action will be documented and maintained onsite as required.



Emergency Response Program



RFAAP has multiple plans and procedures which satisfy the emergency response requirements of 40 CFR Part !?68.95, and were developed to be protectiv

e of human health and the environment. The Disaster Control Plan provides an overarching document for describing procedures, event communication and personnel responsibilities in the event of a disaster, as RFAAP recognizes that the potential for a chemical release exists as secondary to a causative external event, such as a natural event or act of terrorism. RFAAP also maintains a RFAAP Fire Prevention Plan and Hazardous Material Response Plan, as well as other response plans specifically tailored to the personnel at the operations-level and maintenance-level who interact with these processes on a daily basis. 



RFAAP also performs an annual training drill wherein multiple external responders participate with facility personnel in a simulated emergency event to ensure ongoing readiness and familiarity with site response and operations in the event of an actual event requiring coordinated external response.   



Planned Safety Improvements



The completion and start-up of the New D-Line Nitrocellulose Manufacturing Process represents a significant advancement in safety for the facility.  When final prove-out is completed for the new process, the Legacy C-Line Nitrocellulose Manufacturing Process will be shutdown and decommissioned.  Although the New D-Line process will utilize the same RMP-covered substances (i.e., strong nitric acid, oleum, and ammonia), C-Line's older acid storage and mixing processes will be functionally replaced by the newer and upgraded tankage at D-Line.  Additionally, D-Line's SCR will utilize a right-sized satellite ammonia tank, allowing the legacy ammonia storage at the Acid Area and the extended piping run to C-Line to be decommissioned and shutdown as well.  Furthermore, the multi-year project to refurbish and improve the Acid Area Tank Farm, inclusive of strong nitric acid and oleum storage, is in progress and will involve improvements/replacements to the legacy tankage as well as to the secondary containment dikes was completed, an
d this updated infrastructure will continue to support the New D-Line Nitrocellulose Manufacturing Process.
